name: East African Agama
description: This fairly robust lizard has a large head and distinct neck. Its coloration varies depending on sex, age, social status, overall condition, and mood. Females, juveniles, and subordinate males are gray-blue with brownish heads. Dominant males have blue to blue-gray bodies and legs, orange to red heads and necks, and transversely striped tails. At night, all individuals adopt an inconspicuous gray-blue hue.
food_note: Insects and other invertebrates, occasionally small vertebrates, sometimes leaves and flowers
image_alt: East African agama, photo: Prague Zoo archive
proportions: Body length 30–40 cm, with the tail comprising 50–70%; females are smaller than males
reproduction: Females lay 5–7 eggs in a soil pit; incubation lasts 59–69 days.
attractions: The East African agama is a highly active diurnal lizard. Dominant males often perch on elevated spots, overseeing their territory and the females within it. They ward off rivals with vigorous head-bobbing, escalating to swift attacks if needed. During courtship, the male approaches the female from behind, bobbing and sidestepping, attempting to grasp her neck. A willing female raises her head and tail high. Copulation lasts a brief 1–2 minutes.
breeding: We have kept this subspecies since 2013, when it replaced the nominate subspecies of the agama (A. a. agama).
